title: Start with Yourself
content: If you want to lead others, first lead yourself. If you want the respect of others, first respect yourself.

title: Taking notes in the open
content: If I want my mental models (those which resonant highly with my aphantasic form of cognition) to be well-represented in future AI models, which I very much do, then publishing them to a scrape-able medium is the only way to go.

title: Is our pricing right? Too expensive? Not expensive enough?
content: If you cannot get people to use your product for free, you shouldn't be wasting time trying to sell it (yet). You have a much more fundamental concern of product-market fit which needs to be addressed first. It is much easier to figure out how to sell something with user-traction than it is to figure out how to get users in the first place, which requires (the infamous) "building something people want".

title: Code should be as simple as possible, but no simpler.
content: One of the most fundamental insights on the journey from junior to senior developer: complexity COSTS. Simple abstractions with minimal cognitive load are the goal. Maintainability matters much more than raw speed because computer time is cheap and engineer time is expensive. A simple heuristic to grade the degree to which you got it right: how quickly and how painlessly will you be able to add a new feature in three months?

title: Outsourcing cognition
content: The most necessary digital skill of our era may be the ability to sit with a question before reaching for the LLM.
